title: 108_hr4431
content: The Act may be cited as "One Church, One Child Act of 2004". The findings are outlined in Section 2. The Congress finds a shortage of qualified foster and adoptive parents, with a decrease in foster parents despite an increase in children in foster care. There is a significant number of children awaiting adoption, with a growing need for post-adoption support. As many as 126,000 children were awaiting adoption, with an average of 44 months in foster care. The increase in adoptions from foster care has led to a growing need for post-adoption services and knowledgeable service providers. One Church, One Child is a national ministry providing comprehensive services for at-risk children and adoptive families. One Church, One Child is a community-based foster care and adoption ministry founded in 1980 in Chicago, Illinois by Father George Clements. Their mission is to provide services for at-risk children and support adoptive, foster, and kinship families. Over 140,000 children have been placed in adoptive families through their programs. Despite their success, limited federal funding has been received for their recruitment, training, and support services. A federally-funded grant program is needed to support the establishment and expansion of similar programs nationwide. A federally-funded grant program is needed to support the establishment and expansion of programs for the recruitment of foster and adoptive parents based on the One Church, One Child concept. This will benefit abused and neglected children by increasing the pool of qualified adoptive and foster parents. SEC. 3. ONE CHURCH, ONE CHILD GRANTS. Amends Part E of title IV of the Social Security Act to add a grant program for recruiting foster and adoptive parents based on the One Church, One Child concept. The Secretary will provide competitive grants to eligible entities to establish or expand programs that recruit and train foster and adoptive parents through public, private, and faith-based organizations. Eligible entities include state or local governments, public agencies, nonprofit organizations, and private entities. The Secretary will provide competitive grants to eligible entities, including state or local governments, public agencies, nonprofit organizations, and private entities, to establish or expand programs for foster and adoptive parents. Eligible entities must submit an application with project descriptions and other required information to receive funds. The eligible entities must submit an application with project descriptions, including the number of children to be served and services provided to adoptive and foster parents. Coordination with state and local entities is also required. The eligible entities must submit an application with project descriptions, including services provided to adoptive and foster parents, coordination with state and local entities, and cooperation with oversight requirements. An agreement to maintain records, reports, and cooperate with audits as required by the Secretary for oversight purposes. Definition of 'State' includes 50 states, DC, Puerto Rico, US Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and Northern Mariana Islands. Authorization of up to $20,000,000 for fiscal years 2005-2009. Grant funds available for 3 years. The Secretary is authorized to appropriate up to $20,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2005-2009 for the Northern Mariana Islands. Grant funds must be used within 3 years, with any unspent funds returned to the Secretary. Unused funds will be redistributed to eligible entities in need. The Secretary can redistribute any unused grant funds among eligible entities in need. Religious organizations are considered equally for grants as long as they comply with the Establishment Clause. Religious organizations can receive grants under the condition that they adhere to the Establishment Clause. They cannot be discriminated against based on their religious character, and neither the Federal Government nor State/local governments can interfere with their internal governance or religious symbols to be eligible for funding. Religious organizations receiving grants must not alter their internal governance or remove religious symbols to be eligible for funding. Funds cannot be used for sectarian worship, instruction, or proselytization. Religious organizations must adhere to the same regulations as other nongovernmental organizations for fiscal accountability. Religious organizations receiving funds must adhere to fiscal accountability regulations, keeping the funds separate from other organization funds. SEC. 479C. National Clearinghouse for Adoption Promotion and Foster Parent Recruitment Programs; Annual Report to Congress. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to coordinate activities for recruiting foster and adoptive parents and providing support to foster families. The nonprofit organization will coordinate activities for recruiting foster and adoptive parents, providing post-placement support, and collecting information on program effectiveness. The nonprofit organization will coordinate activities for recruiting and training foster and adoptive parents, providing post-placement support, collecting information on program effectiveness, and assisting in report preparation. The nationally recognized, nonprofit adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment organization selected by the Secretary on a competitive basis will provide consultation, training, and assistance in report preparation for evaluating program effectiveness. The organization selected by the Secretary for adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment must have experience in providing consultation and training to faith-based and community organizations, a national reputation in recruiting and training foster and adoptive parents, and extensive experience in establishing programs. The organization chosen by the Secretary for adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment must have experience working with faith-based and community organizations, a national reputation in recruiting and training foster and adoptive parents, and extensive experience in establishing programs based on the One Church, One Child model. Authorization of appropriations is limited to $1,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2005 to 2009. Annual reports must be submitted to Congress detailing the number of entities involved. From 2005 to 2009, the Secretary must submit annual reports to Congress regarding grants made under section 479B. The reports should include the number of entities receiving grants, foster parents and adoptive families recruited, children placed with them, and outcomes of placements. Additional relevant information may also be included for program evaluation.
